basics.name: Leif Simmatis
basics.summary: Digital health researcher with a background in systems neuroscience.

work.name: University of Toronto
work.summary: Developed digital speech biomarkers for neurological diseases. Led development and validation of novel real-world speech data collection tools.

work.name: Winterlight Labs
work.summary: Led validation of speech assessment app in ALS.

volunteer.summary: Led a team of 10 postdoctoral researchers to design and deliver professional development activities for UHN trainees.
Collaborated with a working group to provide comment on FDA and EMA draft guidelines for clinical trial design and regulation.

awards.title: Mitacs Elevate Fellowship
awards.summary: Awarded $120,000 CAD to lead partnership between Speech Production Lab and Winterlight Labs to validate Winterlight speech assessment technology in ALS patients.

awards.title: Robert John Wilson Fellowship
awards.summary: Awarded $10,000 CAD for promising graduate research project in health sciences.

publications.name: Analytical Validation of a Webcam-Based Assessment of Speech Kinematics: Digital Biomarker Evaluation following the V3 Framework
publications.summary: Validated a novel web-based speech assessment system. Demonstrated that digital speech assessment technologies have strong validity compared to lab-based systems, which will enable the use of digital health speech assessments in clinical applications.

publications.name: 3D Video Tracking Technology in the Assessment of Orofacial Impairments in Neurological Disease: Clinical Validation
publications.summary: Demonstrated that facial movement features derived from a deep learning model can capture clinical phenomena in ALS and stroke.

publications.name: Reliability of automatic computer vision-based assessment of orofacial kinematics for telehealth applications
publications.summary: Showed that deep learning-based facial movement features gathered remotely are as reliable as those gathered in a lab setting.

publications.name: Automated Temporal Segmentation of Orofacial Assessment Videos
publications.summary: Found that deep learning-based movement repetition estimator was able to effectively segment videos of orofacial/speech assessments.

publications.name: Concurrent Validity of Automatic Speech and Pause Measures During Passage Reading in ALS
publications.summary: Demonstrated that Wav2Vec (a transformer-based ASR system) could outperform classical speech and pause estimation algorithms in dysarthric speech.

publications.name: Principal components analysis using data collected from healthy individuals on two robotic assessment platforms yields similar behavioral patterns.
publications.summary: Identified that exoskeleton and endpoint robotic systems capture similar patterns of upper-limb motor behaviour, validating the use of the simpler endpoint system.

publications.name: Quantifying changes over 1 year in motor and cognitive skill after transient ischemic attack (TIA) using robotics.
publications.summary: Showed that people who had TIAs or migraines displayed atypical patterns of change on upper-limb robotic assessments for as much as 1-year post-event.

publications.name: Facial Landmark Tracking in Videos of Individuals with Neurological Impairments: Is There a Trade-off Between Smoothness and Accuracy?
publications.summary: Demonstrated that fine tuning deep learning models optimized for smoothness or for accuracy resulted in a tradeoff in performance between better tracking at a frame level, or better tracking at a video level.

publications.name: Assessing various sensorimotor and cognitive functions in people with epilepsy is feasible with robotics.
publications.summary: Patients with epilepsy displayed upper-limb sensorimotor impairments in motor and cognitive assessment domains, and the type/extent of impairment was related to the type of antiepileptic medications prescribed.

publications.name: Statistical measures of motor, sensory and cognitive performance across repeated robot-based testing.
publications.summary: Features of upper-limb motor control gathered using a robot display favourable reliability and consistency properties.

publications.name: The feasibility of assessing cognitive and motor function in multiple sclerosis patients using robotics.
publications.summary: Multiple sclerosis patients displayed mixtures of motor and cognitive impairments, which captured different patterns of disease severity than the standard MS assessment, the EDSS.

publications.name: The impact of transient ischemic attack (TIA) on brain and behavior.
publications.summary: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA) is associated with a variety of motor and cognitive impairments; here, we reviewed the evidence that TIA, despite being a transient event, does not strictly have transient sequelae.

publications.name: The feasibility of using robotic technology to quantify sensory, motor, and cognitive impairments associated with ALS.
publications.summary: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is associated primarily with motor impairments, but here we demonstrate that it is also possible to identify cognitive-motor deficits over and above motor impairments.

publications.name: Using principal component analysis to reduce complex datasets produced by robotic technology in healthy participants.
publications.summary: We characterized patterns of upper limb motor control in a large cohort of health control participants, using data derived from the Kinarm Exoskeleton.

publications.name: Robotic exoskeleton assessment of transient ischemic attack.
publications.summary: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA) is classically viewed as an event of little longterm consequence; however, we showed that up to 2 weeks after a TIA, patients had a variety of motor, sensory, and cognitive-motor deficits as determined using upper-limb robotic assessments.

publications.name: Robotic exoskeleton assessment of transient ischemic attack.
publications.summary: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA) is classically viewed as an event of little longterm consequence; however, we showed that up to 2 weeks after a TIA, patients had a variety of motor, sensory, and cognitive-motor deficits as determined using upper-limb robotic assessments.

projects.name: Development of virtual speech assessment web application.
projects.summary: Led design and validation of a web-based platform for assessing dysarthric speech in neurological diseases. Oversaw creation of AI-powered analytical pipeline for extracting speech biomarkers from audio and video data.

projects.name: Analytical and clinical validation of remote acoustic analysis pipeline in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
projects.summary: Led an academia/industry collaboration with Winterlight Labs to validate their speech analysis technology in ALS. Led teams of research assistants to preprocess large speech datasets and built AI/ML and statistical pipelines for ALS detection.

projects.name: Improving extraction of dysarthric speech biomarkers using automatic speech recognition.
projects.summary: Led a master's degree project that focused on using ASR for improving the extraction of clinically-relevant acoustic features of speech and voice.

projects.name: Cove Neurosciences, Inc.
projects.summary: Acted as head of neuroscience portfolio development and clinical translation at Cove Neuro. Engaged with clients and led formation of successful B2B and academia/industry partnerships.
